metadata.synopsis: Triggers either as an OOM or an AOM when Elminster is already in the camp, or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).
metadata.how_to_trigger: With Gale Companion without an Avatar available, or with Gale as Avatar:- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to SCL_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_SCL_975ef355-b68e-4061-bda8-b774e8ff552fContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.OR- Give Gale at least one magic item, go to CRE_Main_A, and approach Elminster at S_ORI_Gale_ElminsterPoint_CRE_f5a225ef-d123-449f-98e2-53309a21979bContinue through the dialogue until you are sent to camp.- Go to SCL_Main_A- Queue night NIGHT_ORI_Gale_ElminsterVisit

29.speaker: Weary Traveller
29.context: CinematicNodeContext: Glancing around at the general camp area.

32.speaker: Weary Traveller
32.text: Ah, finally he stirs. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.

77.speaker: Narrator
77.text: *Your previous encounter with the old wizard was most likely a simulacrum - the figure before you may well be too.*

55.speaker: Narrator
55.text: *Your previous encounter with the old wizard seems to have left him unflustered - and unmarked.*

71.speaker: Weary Traveller
71.text: I took the liberty of enlisting your cadaverous co-traveller to revive you. You truly should take much better care of yourself, m'boy.

30.speaker: Weary Traveller
30.text: The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.

49.speaker: Gale
49.text: Say nothing. Wait for him to explain himself.

14.speaker: Weary Traveller
14.text: Don't just gawp at me like the dregs of the fishmonger's stall - I've worn out quite some boot leather in order to track you down.

13.speaker: Weary Traveller
13.text: I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.

44.speaker: Weary Traveller
44.text: Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?

47.speaker: Weary Traveller
47.text: But I suppose, after all the calamity that's been laid at your feet, you can be forgiven raw nerves and a sharp tongue...

66.speaker: Gale
66.text: You underestimate me, Elminster. 'She' could be any number of acquaintances.

1.speaker: Weary Traveller
1.text: But there is only one who truly counts, no? One whose favour you crave. One who knows the catastrophe that lurks 'twixt your ribs.

38.speaker: Weary Traveller
38.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

63.speaker: Weary Traveller
63.text: Mystra - the message and the charge I bring you are hers.

10.speaker: Weary Traveller
10.text: You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.

11.speaker: Weary Traveller
11.text: She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.

25.speaker: Weary Traveller
25.text: Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.

61.speaker: Weary Traveller
61.text: You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.

60.speaker: Weary Traveller
60.text: That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.

21.speaker: Gale
21.text: You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.

31.speaker: Gale
31.text: You promised me plain talk, Elminster. Make it plainer still, or we're done here.

45.speaker: Weary Traveller
45.text: The orb. That constant reminder of your past failings. The instrument of your slow, sad, inevitable destruction. It can instead redeem you.

73.speaker: Gale
73.text: I could possibly put an end to the Absolute - if you aided me.

3.speaker: Weary Traveller
3.text: Alas, not the role I've been given in this particular tale. I am but a bare cameo compared to the part that you must play. You and the orb.

27.speaker: Weary Traveller
27.text: Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.

50.speaker: Weary Traveller
50.text: You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: I am Mystra's servant. If this is what she asks of me, so be it.

57.speaker: Weary Traveller
57.text: Your clear-mindedness is a testament to yourself, Gale.

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: That's the cost of Mystra's good graces? Martyrdom?

52.speaker: Weary Traveller
52.text: Remember who she is, Gale. Mortal death is but a passing chapter to a goddess - and to those who win her favour.

28.speaker: Weary Traveller
28.text: Whatever she can grant unto you is infinitely better than whatever you cling to now.

23.speaker: Weary Traveller
23.text: With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.

33.speaker: Weary Traveller
33.context: CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] He's disarming a magic orb within Gale's chest, close to his heart. Elminster gestures towards Gale's heart with an open palm, moving the hand in a small ircular motion, as if soothing or containing the orb within with a charm.

22.speaker: Weary Traveller
22.text: It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.

78.speaker: Weary Traveller
78.text: A shame that we did not cross paths sooner. The orb's thirst for magic is now quenched, yet it already inflicted some damage while you tried to forge ahead.

2.speaker: Weary Traveller
2.text: The ill effects may linger, I'm afraid. Not enough to hamper your mission, I hope.

5.speaker: Weary Traveller
5.text: Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.

72.speaker: Weary Traveller
72.text: And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.

18.speaker: Weary Traveller
18.text: Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.

19.speaker: Gale
19.text: What other choice do I have?

76.speaker: Weary Traveller
76.text: You could flee from Mystra's calling. Live the life of a hermit once again, and succumb to the orb all the same. Only, it will be a death without purpose.

48.speaker: Weary Traveller
48.text: It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.

26.speaker: Gale
26.text: That's more magnanimous of her than I've grown accustomed to. The catch being?

59.speaker: Weary Traveller
59.text: The catch being the exact definition of redemption in Mystra's eyes, and the labour you must undertake in order to attain it.

70.speaker: Weary Traveller
70.text: Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.

64.speaker: Gale
64.text: You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.
64.context: NodeContext: Weary resignation. He's being asked on a suicide mission.
